Submodules¶

pyutil.backup_nt_and_posix module¶

Backup a directory by appending the date and time and copying over.

Motivation¶

This script aims to be platform agnostic and in the long term will be used on Windows, Linux, Mac and Android systems.

Usage¶

python backup_nt_and_posix.py /path/to/dir
pyutil.backup_nt_and_posix.backup_directory(path)[source]¶

Create a backup of a directory. Use the date and time as new name.

Returns:means no error occurred. 0: to signify the success -1 : to signify the failure error string: the exact error string
Return type:None

pyutil.batch_renamer module¶

Renames a directory of files based on a template

Largely argparse and doctest practice. From pydocs tutorials stdlib2. Reformatted. Still uses old style strings as a result.

Examples:

>>> os.listdir("/path/to/dir")
# ['img_1074.jpg', 'img_1076.jpg', 'img_1077.jpg']
>>>  batch_renamer.py /path/to/dir
#  img_1074.jpg --> Ashley_0.jpg
#  img_1076.jpg --> Ashley_1.jpg
#  img_1077.jpg --> Ashley_2.jpg

Todo

First things first ensure it works at all. Then we should add some doctests maybe.

pyutil.dlink module¶

Symlink all of the files in one directory into another.

Usage:

`ln -s path/to/dest/* [path/to/src]`
pyutil.dlink.dlink(dest, src)[source]¶

Symlinks a directory from another one.

Utilize in an analogous way to Unix idiom::
ln -s path/to/dir/*
Parameters:
  • dest – The directory where the original files are located.
  • src – Optional argument indicating the directory where the symlinks

are to be created.

If the src argument isn’t provided, it is assumed that the current working directory is the src dir.

Returns:None

pyutil.env module¶

Simple module that pretty prints the user’s environment variables.

This is actually implemented as an IPython magic but to make it easier to use in a typical Python REPL it’s also implemented here.

The if name == ‘__main__’ is left off so that it can be run directly or sourced.

pyutil.find_pics module¶

pyutil.inspect_module module¶

Explore the namespace and attributes of a module.

If no argument is provided then use the name bound to the local IPython object.

However Python3.6 now has the builtin module ‘pyclbr’ so this entire script may be irrelevant.

pyutil.inspect_module.main(mod_name)[source]¶

Credit for this function in particular goes entirely to: Vasudev Ram mod_attrs_and_types.py

pyutil.itersrc module¶

pyutil.itersrc.iter_source_code(paths)[source]¶

Iterate over all Python source files in C{paths}.

Taken with almost no modifications from pyflakes. This would be a great function to call with os.listdir(‘root’) output.

@param paths: A list of paths. Directories will be recursed into and

any .py files found will be yielded. Any non-directories will be yielded as-is.

param paths:

pyutil.lazy_downloader module¶

Automating the process of grabbing plain text files from the internet.

Usage:
lazy_downloader url output_filename

If filename already exists on the system it will NOT be overwritten, and the script will crash.

pyutil.linktree module¶

From Python3.6 Examples in Ubuntu repositories.

Minor modifications for flake8, pydocstyle etc.

linktree

Make a copy of a directory tree with symbolic links to all files in the original tree. All symbolic links go to a special symbolic link at the top, so you can easily fix things if the original source tree moves.

Usage::
mklinks oldtree newtree

See also “mkreal”.

pyutil.linktree.linknames(old, new, link)[source]¶

Recursively symlink a directory tree.

pyutil.linktree.main()[source]¶

Handle user inputs and initialize arguments.

pyutil.mv_to_repo module¶

Moves files from anywhere in the home directory to the dotfiles repo.

This is a script I’ve been using for the better part of a year, so while the docstring formatting isn’t consistent and there are a couple odd sections, this script has served a very utilitiarian purpose.

May refactor one day. But it continues to work.

pyutil.mv_to_repo.backup_file(src)[source]¶

Backs up file ‘src’

pyutil.mv_to_repo.main()[source]¶

Dispatch the remaining implementation of the module.

Determine if a file name is in the current directory or absolute path. Then set up a relative path from $HOME. Use the root of the repo as the new root and move the file there, all while creating directories and backups.

Runs checks, calls func to backup file ‘src’, moves it to the dotfiles repo and symlinks it. Moves file to a hardcoded path but will be generalized to take as an argument.

Parameters:of file to backup, move and symlink. (Name) –
Assumes:
User runs the script from inside the folder of the file they want to move.
pyutil.mv_to_repo.repo_dir_check(dest)[source]¶

Checks that the directory is in the repository and make one otherwise.

pyutil.mv_to_repo.sys_checks()[source]¶

Checks that system requirements are met.

pyutil.nvim-profiling module¶

pyutil.ptags module¶

Create a tags file for Python programs, usable with vi.

Tagged are:
  • functions (even inside other defs or classes)
  • classes
  • filenames

Warns about files it cannot open.

No warnings about duplicate tags.

Snagged from the scripts dir in python3.6-examples.

TODO::

Add docstrings. Use ipdb and step through while watching the tags var. Initially it was defined outside the ifmain loop.

I moved it, but without the global keyword I don’t get how any changes to tags in treat_file will propogate back to main.

Otherwise add in pep257 compliant params. Try different styles and see what you like.

pyutil.ptags.main()[source]¶

Handle CLAs and work with writing the tags file.

pyutil.ptags.treat_file(filename)[source]¶

Find usable matches for tags file.

pyutil.rclone module¶

pyutil.script_helper module¶

Common utility functions used by various script execution tests

e.g. test_cmd_line, test_cmd_line_script and test_runpy

pyutil.script_helper.assert_python_failure(*args, **env_vars)[source]¶

Assert that running the interpreter with args and optional environment variables env_vars fails (rc != 0) and return a (return code, stdout, stderr) tuple.

See assert_python_ok() for more options.

pyutil.script_helper.assert_python_ok(*args, **env_vars)[source]¶

Assert that running the interpreter with args and optional environment variables env_vars succeeds (rc == 0) and return a (return code, stdout, stderr) tuple.

If the __cleanenv keyword is set, env_vars is used as a fresh environment.

Python is started in isolated mode (command line option -I), except if the __isolated keyword is set to False.

pyutil.script_helper.interpreter_requires_environment()[source]¶

Returns True based on sys.executable.

If the interpreter requires environment variables in order to be able to run at all.

This is designed to be used with @unittest.skipIf() to annotate tests that need to use an assert_python*() function to launch an isolated mode (-I) or no environment mode (-E) sub-interpreter process.

A normal build & test does not run into this situation but it can happen when trying to run the standard library test suite from an interpreter that doesn’t have an obvious home with Python’s current home finding logic.

Setting PYTHONHOME is one way to get most of the testsuite to run in that situation. PYTHONPATH or PYTHONUSERSITE are other common environment variables that might impact whether or not the interpreter can start.

pyutil.script_helper.kill_python(p)[source]¶

Run the given Popen process until completion and return stdout.

pyutil.script_helper.make_pkg(pkg_dir, init_source='')[source]¶
pyutil.script_helper.make_script(script_dir, script_basename, source, omit_suffix=False)[source]¶
pyutil.script_helper.make_zip_pkg(zip_dir, zip_basename, pkg_name, script_basename, source, depth=1, compiled=False)[source]¶
pyutil.script_helper.make_zip_script(zip_dir, zip_basename, script_name, name_in_zip=None)[source]¶
pyutil.script_helper.run_python_until_end(*args, **env_vars)[source]¶
pyutil.script_helper.spawn_python(*args, stdout=-1, stderr=-2, **kw)[source]¶

Run a Python subprocess with the given arguments.

kw is extra keyword args to pass to subprocess.Popen. Returns a Popen object.

pyutil.strip_space module¶

Strip only trailing whitespace from a file.

Leading whitespace is significant in Python so don’t touch it.

Requires::
Python 3.4>

pyutil.sys_checks module¶

Module to check a user is utilizing the proper version of python.

Even outside of the 2 to 3 incompatibilities, the standard library introduces new modules often enough that it’s useful to check.

Utilized by importing as so.

Assumes:

All functions are imported as the module will immediately exit if directly executed.
pyutil.sys_checks.py_gt(min_py_version)[source]¶

Check a user’s python version is higher than some floor value.

For example, the argparse was only introduced in python3.2.

Everything utilizing it as a result needs to check that the right version is setup.

Parameters:min_py_version – The lowest version of python that can be used
Returns:None
pyutil.sys_checks.py_lt(max_py_version)[source]¶

Check a user’s python version is lower than some ceiling value.

If you’ll crash on python3.4 but work on 3.3, call this func with 3.3.

Parameters:max_py_version – The highest version of python that can be used
Type:int or float or tuple
Returns:None
pyutil.sys_checks.test_linux()[source]¶

Not a unit test but checks that the user is on Linux OS.

pyutil.zillow-api module¶

Module contents¶

This package is undergoing a thorough rewriting.

Set up logging in a general manner and use pkg_resources provided by setuptools in order to create the directory as a namespace package.
